title: Maker Wheel Precision Shims
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: These shims where made with Tinkercad and can be edited online at https://www.tinkercad.com/things/5sgQIUWQM9C The idea behind this was to produce 3D printed percision shim for Mini V-Wheels (http://amzn.to/1OoR7po). The short set are ~2mm tall and are designed to be placed between the bolt or nut as a precision shim. Whereas the taller set are ~6.35mm or 0.25 inches and intended to act as an offset from a plate acting as sandwich between the plate and wheel to form a stanchion. Also check out the "how to" video at https://youtu.be/L2RDBXO1Lkg as well as our YouTube Channel at http://youtube.DIY3DTech.com for more projects like this or visit us at httP//www.DIY3DTech.com for projects and build notes!

Printer:

Da vinici

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

90% or better

Notes: Also use the "slow" setting with 100% (or as close as you can get) with smallest layer highlight possible on your printer as these are precision prints.

title: Micro Polyhedron Vertices - Revisited for PLA
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I redid the SCAD file for the Micro Polyhedron Vertices. It's not parametric yet, so if you want to change something you'll have to dig into the code. It's much less code then the original, and renders a lot faster.
I changed the plong sizes to be smaller, so you can print and build it with PLA (which is more rigid then ABS)
I did not create a rafted 16 at once version. They stick to the bed without issue on my printer (PLA related?) so I printed them one at a time.

Same as the Micro Polyhedron Vertices.
10x type 1
10x type 2
Assemble.
Give it to your cat.

comments.text: Great object!  I printed this in ABS, because the plongs on the parent object were too big, and I couldn't be bothered to go in and shrink them when somebody had already done it.  They fit like a dream: strong enough to hold, but easy enough my 5-year-old son can play with them, which was the whole idea. :)

author: NorcoT

title: Scout Trooper Helmet (Hi-res)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Looking forward to seeing some of these printed! I thought I should get all the Imperial Helmets done before I start on the armor pieces. It's alot easier to get things scaled when you are working on the same type of items, so doing all the helmets together seemed the obvious route and vice versa. This does need some support on pieces, notably Parts 13 and 14, others can probably do without. All pieces have been repaired, double checked in slicer, simplify3D and makerware - I really can't do any more checking than I have done. Everything reports manifold meshes and slicing previews are good. If you have issues slicing any of these files please let me know which file and what software you are using. There are alot of really low poly Scout Trooper helmets out there, none of them suitable for printing.. now there is! :) Assembly instructions can be found below:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bmhVGNXDR34

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Notes: I kept the thickness to a minimum to save filament, so I would probably put a touch more infil in parts 1 through 10 as some of the parts have some thin sections that could do with some extra infil. Part 19 is optional, people will most likely use a Ski goggle visor or similar, but I included a smooth version of the goggles for those wishing to print it.

comments.author: bromego

comments.text:
I don't think it's possible to flip the front until the dome is flattened on top. I've just bonded mine all together with slurry.
For the slurry I save all my support material and scrap in jars, add pure acetone (nail varnish remover) in various quantities for different types of slurry. Less acetone makes a slurry like melted toffee (or I guess taffee if you're using bondo :) ). That's great for strengthening the inside of thin prints and bonding inner joints. More acetone and you get a creamy consistency which is great for painting on to smooth surface areas.
To ease the squeeze when putting the helmet on I prised the aperture open with a chopstick and heated the plastic with a heat gun so it bent slightly.
All assembled, sanding finished tomorrow then primer and paint!!

remixed_from.author: VoltaicLoki
remixed_from.title: Makerfarm Prusa i3v Auto-bed leveling Servo Mount

description.text:
With a rear-mounted fan duct blocking the vertical space  behind the hotend, the only options for a "typical" servo mount either blocks the extruder mounting bolt or puts the servo far forward with a long probe arm.
clouhg42's Hexagon fan shroud frees up a lot of internal space, enough that I can mount the servo body internally and low with a shorter probe arm off the side while keeping the extruder screw accessible. The only disadvantage is that the Y offset is approx 45mm.
The servo flange is recessed so that the M3 side screw also holds it in place. Note that I had to cut out a section from the duct to fit the servo in. Rather than dismantle everything I just carved it out with a hot knife, but that may not be the best approach.

description.text:
A toilet paper holder that can simply be refilled by pushing a roll of toilet paper from beneath. It is completely supportless and can be printed on almost any printer. A quick demonstration:
http://youtu.be/n13LZ1clkAQ

To make this, you will need several things.
  • 2 M4 30mm+ screws to secure the holder;
  • 1 130mm 4mm axle to hold the lid in place;
  • All the printed parts supplied on this page;
  • Glue;
    • Print: 1 lid, 1 left side, 1 right side and 2 holders. The design is completely supportless and all parts are very easy to print. mount the holders in either side by inserting them in the slots and securing them with a M4 screw inserted at the back. The screw taps in the plastic on the front side of the slot, so be careful with drilling the holes. The holders are slightly asymmetrical, the thicker side needs to go on the outside so they will naturally fall outward. Mount the axle in the lid, then mount the lid between both sides. Glue both sides together when everything fits nicely. After this, you can mount the toilet paper holder to the wall of your bathroom.

description.text:
I needed a tray of compartments to put screws in when taking laptops apart and the like so I printed one. I designed it with a noddy little OpenSCAD script so I can make one with long and thin compartments for airbrush needles or whatever.
I'll probably update this at some point to allow different thickness walls between compartments and for the outer walls and maybe for rounded bottom compartments.

The variables in the .scad file should be fairly self explanatory, compx and compy are the size of each compartment in mm; wall is the wall thickness (again in mm); nox and noy are the number of compartments in x and y and deep is the depth of each compartment.

Yet another desktop vacuum former. This one operates with a heatgun and vacuum (of course). Designed to be printable at Ponoko and released for FREE. http://www.ponoko.com/design-your-own/products/desktop-vacuum-former-with-3-files-6514 Requires: Heatgun, vacuum, machine screws, glue, aluminum foil Designed for laser cut in MDF or wood .25 inches thick Same dimensions as makerbot except on its side.

Assembly instructions here: http://support.ponoko.com/entries/20509538-desktop-vacuum-former Assembly instructions:

  • Insert the perforated middle board and the bottom board into one of the end pieces. See pic 1.
    http://support.ponoko.com/attachments/token/vymlueqea2w5nzz/?name=Assemble_Vac_Former_-1.jpg

  • Attach the other end piece onto the other side forming a modified 'H'. See pic 2.
    http://support.ponoko.com/attachments/token/0e9v8ythj44eubn/?name=Assemble_Vac_Former_-2.jpg

  • Place the boards onto the right side board. Use the machine screw joints to secure in place. Glue together. Ensure that there are no air leaks along the seams especially at the bottom board and the perforated middle board. See pic 3.
    http://support.ponoko.com/attachments/token/les09twbxhu8ix2/?name=Assemble_Vac_Former_-3.jpg

  • Place the left side board onto the other side. Secure in place with machine screws. Glue together. Again ensure that there are no air leaks at the seams.

  • Line inside and top with aluminum foil.

  • Place mold form onto perforated middle board. Cover any excess holes with duct tape.

  • Place plastic onto insert frame and use machine screws to lock onto insert frame.

  • Option 1: Use string to create handles on either side to hang plastic down over mold. String is laced underneath insert through each side to form 2 loops to support the insert by hand (pic needed)

  • Option 2: use long machine screws to create "table" with insert. 4 Long machine screws are used with 2 additional nuts per screw. Nuts secure plastic while screws serve as legs that lift insert with plastic over the mold form (pic needed)

  • Place vacuum nozzle into bottom hole and heat gun into top hole.

  • Place lid on.

  • Turn on heat gun.

  • when ready turn on vacuum.

  • Plastic will form to mold.

  • remove plastic and trim.

description.text: I just printed a Heptagonal-Finger-Ring for my wife. I like 3d printed jewelry. And I also like to work with heptagons. I dont't get that chance very often, since they don't make patterns that easy - at least not in an euclidian space that doesn't cause your mind to explode http://www.local-guru.net/blog/2011/10/8/3D-printed-Heptagonal-Finger-Ring

3D printable bottle stopper for resealing wine bottles. I've made this in halves (that need to be glued together) mainly for strength but have also included the parts as one piece. I think they should work but the handle will need to be printed with support. It prints and works well when using the halves. I use a small piece of 3mm filament about 12.5mm 1/2 inch as the axle to connect the handle to the plunger but there is 1.75 mm option included. The stopper/bung part needs to be printed in Ninjaflex with 100% infill. The stopper/bung works and actually creates a water tight seal not sure how effective it will be in the long term. I've added two wider bungs, I tried the tightest version and it is very tight so I have added another one that shouldn't be as tight. One thing I noticed though, if your putting it in the fridge it does loosen off as it contracts from the cold. Caution
Depending on what materials you use it may not be food safe so use at your own risk. Ninjaflex doesn't contain any known toxins according to their website. It shouldn't come into contact with the wine anyway.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa Mendel i2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

25%

Notes: These are the setting I used for the plunger and the handle, the cap I printed 100% infill. This is important : The bung was printed 100% infill. I printed many bungs at different infills trying to get it to work and this was the best design/infill I achieved so far

• Glue together the two halves of the plunger once stuck re-drill the hole in the top of the plunger in necessary
  • Slide the bung onto the plunger
  • Insert the plunger into the cap
  • Cut a length of filament about 12.5 mm or 1/2 inch
  • Clean out the grooves in the handle that will take the filament make sure the piece of filament will fit in the grooves once the two halves of the handle are put together
  • Insert the piece of filament into the hole in the plunger
  • Glue the two halves of the handle with the filament sandwiched between the two, be careful not to get glue in the hole of the plunger
  • Let everything set before trying to use the stopper because quite a bit of strain is exerted on the parts

title: Case for simple QRP Endfed Transformer

description.text:
Case for a simple QRP broadband transformer for a half wave end fed (HWEF) Antenna. In this case, the transformer is for the 11m Band (CB-Band).
The Antenna itself is an about 0.95*Lambda/2 wire. You should a current balun into the coax about 1-2m from the transformer to the TRX. This helps to keep HF out of your shack and use the coax as counterpoise. There is also a file with a Meshmixer Support added to the holes if required. The top of the case can be fixed with M3 screws, but you need to drill the thread into the plastic.

description.text:
Another spool holder that mounts horizontally (why fight gravity?). This ones fits my UltiMachine 5lb spool, which has a 39mm (1.5 inches) diameter hole. The OpenSCAD file is parametric in case it needs to be adapted for different spool types.
The STL file is unnecessarily large because I set the OpenSCAD accuracy parameter ($fn) stupidly high. Feel free to re-render using $fn = 60 for a smaller STL file.

The base includes some hollow hemispheres that could hold something sticky like rubber or sticky-tac in case it starts to wander. It also makes it look a super-cool moon base.
No lubricant was required, but that may depend a bit on the spool plastic type and the printer plastic type (PLA in this case).

This is a pinch valve for 6mm silicon tubing, made from laser-cut 3mm acrylic, stacked and held together with machine screws. It's ideal for controlling the flow of air, water, fruit juice, hard liquor, or whatever you desire. It's ideal for controlling the flow of stuff you don't want to risk contaminating with a regular valve, and as a result it's intrinsically food-safe. Power and control is provided by a lightweight '9g' hobby servo; the silicon tubing is simply a push-fit into the top of the valve arrangement. The photos and video are of an earlier prototype; the uploaded design is slightly refined, but functionally identical. You can see it in action here: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4raXnoKUtow

Bolts must be at least the length specified, but can be longer. If you find M2 screws longer than 12mm for an affordable price, let me know, though! The servo I used is a Hextronik HXT900, but pretty much any cheap 9g micro servo will work. Some may require some changes to the bottom 2 layers to fit their housings.
  • Cut the parts out of 3mm acrylic with a laser-cutter.
  • Attach your servo with M2 machine screws to the bottom-most layer (the one with cutouts for the top of the servo and the small holes for the screws. The screw head should be on the acrylic side, with the nut under the servo mount.
  • Lay the second and third layers on top of the first. Take a servo horn and cut the end off so it will fit within the cutout made by the third layer.
  • Screw an M2 machine screw through the horn about 8.5mm from the center, with the screw head facing down - eg, so the screw will be 'upside down' when attached to the servo.
  • Connect the servo to your device and set it to the counter-clockwise-most position. Attach the servo horn so it's parallel with the body of the servo.
  • Now start assembling the body of the valve from the other end. Put M3 screws through the corner holes of the top 3 (identical) layers. Next, place flat washers on top of those, then the third, second, and finally first (with the servo attached) layers. Attach the M3 nuts and tighten.
  • Turning the valve right-side up, drop the 3 plastic rollers onto the shaft formed by the M2 screw coming out of the horn. Take an M2 nut and screw it down a little, not so far that it prevents the rollers from turning. Use glue or epoxy to hold the nut in place.
    • Congratulations, you've assembled a pinch valve! Give it a try!

title: Filament Cleaner for Series 1 Type A Machines printer

description.text: No screws no drilling just a simple add on to standard filament roler

• Print the filament cleaner as solid.
  • Cut a foam block 26mm x 26mm x 16 mm to act as a cleaner.
  • Cut a cross in the middle of the foam block so you can poke the filament through it after it is inserted into the cleaner. My cuts where about 15mm long.
  • Insert the foam block into the hole so the cross lines up with the holes for the filament.
  • Put the filament cleaner on top of the standard roller that came with your Series 1 printer.
  • Push the filament through the cleaner.
    • Make sure it slides easily through the cleaner, if it is tight it will damage your printer
